author: ralexstokes
content: seems like kate commitments will work here as long as you have a deterministic mapping from the natural numbers to your elements A B C D

author: ralexstokes
content: you can use them for a vector commitment so if you vector is [ A B C X ] then you can prove any subset in a single proof and can prove exclusion for D by showing it evaluates to X

author: samwilsn
content:
Yes, the elements have a deterministic ordering, so I think we can use the vector commitment.

Say the committer (Alice) generates a commitment for [A, B, C, Q]

Can Bob generate a proof for C without knowing Q (or B without C & Q)?

author: ralexstokes
content: yup, thats the direct case of kzg, just proving that the polynomial committed to evaluates to that element at that point, `f(x) = y`

author: ralexstokes
content: you can batch proofs but you need more polynomial manipulations on top of the "basic" proof

author: ralexstokes
content: so you'd have a commitment C to the polynomial formed by Lagrange interpolation of your data `{0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:Q}`

author: ralexstokes
content: then the "opening" is a proof (along w/ the value if needed) that the polynomial indeed evaluates to say `C` at the point `2`

author: samwilsn
content: It seems like Bob would need to know Q to generate the lagrange interpolation, no?
